facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 126 of 1960 was filed by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: Criminal Appeal No. 126 of 1960. Appeal by special leave from the Judgment and order dated November 23, 1959, of the Punjab High Court in Criminal Revision No. 1445 of 1959.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the Judgment and order dated November 23, 1959, of the Punjab High Court in Criminal Revision No. 1445 of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: Criminal Appeal No. 126 of 1960. Appeal by special leave from the Judgment and order dated November 23, 1959, of the Punjab High Court in Criminal Revision No. 1445 of 1959.

facts.text: Judgment of the Court delivered by HIDAYATULLAH, J. on January 25, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: 1962. January 25. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by HIDAYATULLAH, J.-This is an appeal by one Dault Ram who was prosecuted under s. 182 of the Indian Penal Code

facts.text: Dault Ram was prosecuted under section 182 of the Indian Penal Code.

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal by one Dault Ram who was prosecuted under s. 182 of the Indian Penal Code and sentenced to imprisonment for three months.

facts.text: Dault Ram was sentenced to imprisonment for three months.

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal by one Dault Ram who was prosecuted under s. 182 of the Indian Penal Code and sentenced to imprisonment for three months. His revision application

facts.text: Revision application in the High Court of Punjab at Chandigarh was dismissed in limine.

anchor.surface_text: His revision application in the High Court of Punjab at Chandigarh was dismissed in limini but he obtained special leave from this companyrt and has filed this appeal.

facts.text: Dault Ram obtained special leave from this court.

anchor.surface_text: His revision application in the High Court of Punjab at Chandigarh was dismissed in limini but he obtained special leave from this companyrt and has filed this appeal.

facts.text: Appellant Dault Ram was working as a Patwari.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was working as a Patwari and on August 19, 1958, he wrote a letter to the Tehsildar of Pathankot that on the previous day he had been set upon

facts.text: On August 19, 1958, appellant wrote a letter to the Tehsildar of Pathankot.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was working as a Patwari and on August 19, 1958, he wrote a letter to the Tehsildar of Pathankot that on the previous day he had been set upon by two persons Hans Raj and Kans Raj who beat him severely and robbed him of certain of his official papers

facts.text: In the letter, appellant alleged that on the previous day (August 18, 1958) he had been set upon by Hans Raj and Kans Raj who beat him severely and robbed him of official papers and some money.

anchor.surface_text: that on the previous day he had been set upon by two persons Hans Raj and Kans Raj who beat him severely and robbed him of certain of his official papers and some money, which was with him, partly belonging to him and partly to the Government.

facts.text: Money robbed was partly belonging to appellant and partly to the Government.

anchor.surface_text: robbed him of certain of his official papers and some money, which was with him, partly belonging to him and partly to the Government.

facts.text: At the end of the letter, appellant stated it was written for the Tehsildar's information.

anchor.surface_text: At the end of the letter which he wrote to the Tehsildar, he stated that the letter was written for his information.

facts.text: Tehsildar forwarded the letter to the Sub-Divisional Officer.

anchor.surface_text: The Tehsildar, however, forwarded the letter to the Sub-Divisional Officer who in his turn sent it on to the police.

facts.text: Sub-Divisional Officer sent the letter to the police.

anchor.surface_text: The Tehsildar, however, forwarded the letter to the Sub-Divisional Officer who in his turn sent it on to the police.

facts.text: Police enquired into the facts and reported that the allegations in the letter were false.

anchor.surface_text: The police enquired into the facts and reported that the allegations in letter were false.

facts.text: Appellant entered into compromise with Hans Raj and Kans Raj.

anchor.surface_text: Meanwhile, it appears that the appellant entered into some sort of companypromise with Hans Raj and Kans Raj and wrote another letter saying that as they were his relatives and he had found the papers and money, the proceedings if any be dropped

facts.text: Appellant wrote another letter saying he had found the papers and money, and proceedings be dropped.

anchor.surface_text: Meanwhile, it appears that the appellant entered into some sort of companypromise with Hans Raj and Kans Raj and wrote another letter saying that as they were his relatives and he had found the papers and money, the proceedings if any be dropped and the papers be companysigned to the record room.

facts.text: Tehsildar asked the police that a calendar be drawn up.

anchor.surface_text: The matter however was pursued further and when the report of the police came that the allegations in the original letter were false, the Tehsildar asked the police that a calendar be drawn up.

facts.text: Police launched prosecution against appellant under s. 182 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: The police however launched a prosecution against the appellant under s. 182 of the Indian Penal Code, and after due trial, the appellant was found guilty of that offence and was sentenced to three months rigorous imprisonment.

facts.text: After due trial, appellant found guilty and sentenced to three months rigorous imprisonment.

anchor.surface_text: The police however launched a prosecution against the appellant under s. 182 of the Indian Penal Code, and after due trial, the appellant was found guilty of that offence and was sentenced to three months rigorous imprisonment.

facts.text: Appellant's appeal and revision failed.

anchor.surface_text: His appeal and revision failed and we have been informed that the appellant has served out his entire sentence.

facts.text: Appellant has served out his entire sentence.

anchor.surface_text: His appeal and revision failed and we have been informed that the appellant has served out his entire sentence.

facts.text: No complaint in writing as required by s. 195 CrPC was presented by the public servant concerned (Tehsildar).

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand what we find is that a companyplaint by the Tehsildar was number filed at all, but a charge sheet was put in by the Station House Officer.

facts.text: Police filed charge sheet by Station House Officer.

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand what we find is that a companyplaint by the Tehsildar was number filed at all, but a charge sheet was put in by the Station House Officer.

facts.text: Tehsildar asked for a calendar after allegations disproved, and this paper was filed with charge sheet.

anchor.surface_text: The learned companynsel for the State Government tries to support the action by submitting that s. 195 had been companyplied with inasmuch as when the allegations had been disproved, the letter of the Superintendent of Police was forwarded to the Tehsildar and he asked for a calendar.

facts.text: Court finds that the trial was without jurisdiction ab initio.

anchor.surface_text: The companynizance of the case was therefore wrongly assumed by the companyrt without the companyplaint in writing of the public servant namely the Tehsildar in this case. The trial was thus without jurisdiction ab inito and the companyviction cannot be maintained.

concepts.unlisted_description: Prohibition on court taking cognizance of certain offences without written complaint by public servant

anchor.surface_text: The words of s. 195 of the Criminal Procedure Code are explicit. The section reads as follows No Court shall take cognizance- a  of any offence punishable under sections 172 to 188 of the Indian Penal Code, except on the complaint in writing of the public servant concerned, or of some other public servant to whom he is subordinate The words of the section, namely, that the complaint has to be in writing by the public servant concerned and that no court shall take cognizance except on such a complaint clearly show that in every instance the court must be moved by the appropriate public servant.

concepts.interpretation: Requires complaint in writing by public servant concerned or subordinate; absolute bar on court taking cognizance otherwise; police charge-sheet insufficient.

anchor.surface_text: The words of s. 195 of the Criminal Procedure Code are explicit. The section reads as follows No Court shall take cognizance- a  of any offence punishable under sections 172 to 188 of the Indian Penal Code, except on the complaint in writing of the public servant concerned, or of some other public servant to whom he is subordinate The words of the section, namely, that the complaint has to be in writing by the public servant concerned and that no court shall take cognizance except on such a complaint clearly show that in every instance the court must be moved by the appropriate public servant. We have to decide therefore whether the Tehsildar can be said to be the public servant concerned and if he had not filed the complaint in writing, whether the police officers in filing the charge sheet had satisfied the requirements of s. 195. The words no court shall take cognizance have been interpreted on more than one occasion and they show that there is an absolute bar against the court taking seisin of the case except in the manner provided by the section.

concepts.interpretation: Absolute bar against court assuming jurisdiction without prescribed complaint; previously interpreted similarly.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: for his information. We are prepared to assume that he expected that some action would be taken. In fact his second letter that he had companypromised

anchor.surface_text: The cognizance of the case was therefore wrongly assumed by the court without the complaint in writing of the public servant namely the Tehsildar in this case. The trial was thus without jurisdiction ab initio and the conviction cannot be maintained.

concepts.interpretation: Trial vitiated from beginning due to lack of complaint under s.195 CrPC; conviction unsustainable.

issues.text: The only question in this case is whether a complaint in writing as required by s. 195 had been presented by the public servant concerned.

anchor.surface_text: His appeal and revision failed and we have been informed that the appellant has served out his entire sentence. The only question in this case is whether a complaint in writing as required by s. 195 had been presented by the public servant concerned.

issues.text: The question is therefore whether under the provisions of s. 195, it was not incumbent on the Tehsildar to present a complaint in writing against the appellant and not leave the court to be moved by the police by putting in a charge sheet.

We have to decide therefore whether the Tehsildar can be said to be the public servant concerned and if he had not filed the complaint in writing, whether the police officers in filing the charge sheet had satisfied the requirements of s. 195.

issues.text: whether the offence under s. 182 of the Penal Code, if any, was complete when the appellant had moved the Tehsildar for action.

anchor.surface_text: Now the offence under s. 182 of the Penal Code, if any, was undoubtedly complete when the appellant had moved the Tehsildar for action. Section 182 does not require that action must always be taken if the person who moves the public servant knows or believes that action would be taken.

arguments.claim: Section 195 CrPC was complied with because after the allegations were disproved, the Superintendent of Police's letter was forwarded to the Tehsildar who asked for a calendar, and this paper filed with the charge sheet satisfies s.195.

anchor.surface_text: The learned counsel for the State Government tries to support the action by submitting that s. 195 had been complied with inasmuch as when the allegations had been disproved, the letter of the Superintendent of Police was forwarded to the Tehsildar and he asked for a calendar.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: llant believed that some action would be taken  and he had numberreason to doubt that it would number  the offence under that section was companyplete

arguments.court_reasoning: this is not a due compliance with the provisions of that section. What the section contemplates is that the complaint must be in writing by the public servant concerned and there is no such compliance in the present case.

arguments.claim: The public servant who was moved by the appellant was undoubtedly the Tehsildar.

anchor.surface_text: The only question in this case is whether a complaint in writing as required by s. 195 had been presented by the public servant concerned. The public servant who was moved by the appellant was undoubtedly the Tehsildar.

arguments.claim: The appellant moved the Tehsildar on false averments of facts and anticipated action on the part of his superior officer.

anchor.surface_text: Whether the appellant wanted the Tehsildar to take action or not, the fact remains that he moved the Tehsildar on what is stated to be a false averment of facts. He had charged Hans Raj and Kans Raj with offences under the Penal Code and he had moved his superior officer for action even though he might have stated in the letter that it was only for his information. We are prepared to assume that he expected that some action would be taken. In fact his second letter that he had compromised the matter and the proceedings might be dropped clearly shows that he anticipated some action on the part of his superior officer.

arguments.claim: s.195 CrPC explicitly requires that no court shall take cognizance of offences under ss.172-188 IPC except on complaint in writing of the public servant concerned or subordinate, and the court must be moved by the appropriate public servant.

anchor.surface_text: The words of s. 195 of the Criminal Procedure Code are explicit. The section reads as follows No Court shall take cognizance- (a) of any offence punishable under sections 172 to 188 of the Indian Penal Code, except on the complaint in writing of the public servant concerned, or of some other public servant to whom he is subordinate The words of the section, namely, that the complaint has to be in writing by the public servant concerned and that no court shall take cognizance except on such a complaint clearly show that in every instance the court must be moved by the appropriate public servant.

arguments.claim: The words 'no court shall take cognizance' create an absolute bar against the court taking seisin except as provided by s.195.

anchor.surface_text: We have to decide therefore whether the Tehsildar can be said to be the public servant concerned and if he had not filed the complaint in writing, whether the police officers in filing the charge sheet had satisfied the requirements of s. 195. The words no court shall take cognizance have been interpreted on more than one occasion and they show that there is an absolute bar against the court taking seisin of the case except in the manner provided by the section.

arguments.claim: The offence under s.182 IPC was complete when the appellant moved the Tehsildar, as s.182 does not require that action must always be taken if the person believes action would be taken.

anchor.surface_text: Now the offence under s. 182 of the Penal Code, if any, was undoubtedly complete when the appellant had moved the Tehsildar for action. Section 182 does not require that action must always be taken if the person who moves the public servant knows or believes that action would be taken. In making his report to the Tehsildar therefore, if the appellant believed that some action would be taken and he had no reason to doubt that it would not  the offence under that section was complete.

arguments.claim: It was incumbent that the complaint in writing be made by the Tehsildar as the public servant concerned.

anchor.surface_text: It was therefore incumbent, if the prosecution was to be launched, that the complaint in writing should be made by the Tehsildar as the public servant concerned in this case.

arguments.claim: No complaint in writing by the Tehsildar was filed; instead a charge sheet was put in by the Station House Officer.

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand what we find is that a complaint by the Tehsildar was not filed at all, but a charge sheet was put in by the Station House Officer.

arguments.claim: The court wrongly assumed cognizance without the required complaint in writing by the Tehsildar; the trial was without jurisdiction ab initio and the conviction cannot be maintained.

anchor.surface_text: The cognizance of the case was therefore wrongly assumed by the court without the complaint in writing of the public servant namely the Tehsildar in this case. The trial was thus without jurisdiction ab initio and the conviction cannot be maintained.

holdings.text: The public servant who was moved by the appellant was undoubtedly the Tehsildar.

anchor.surface_text: The public servant who was moved by the appellant was undoubtedly the Tehsildar. Whether the appellant wanted the Tehsildar to take action or number, the fact remains that he moved the Tehsildar on what is stated to be a false averment of facts. He had charged Hans Raj and Kans Raj with offences under the Penal Code and he had moved his superior officer for action even though he might have stated in the letter that it was only for his information. We are prepared to assume that he expected that some action would be taken. In fact his second letter that he had companypromised the matter and the proceedings might be dropped clearly shows that he anticipated some action on the part of his superior officer.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appellant gave false information directly to Tehsildar, making him the public servant concerned under s.195 CrPC.

holdings.text: The offence under s. 182 of the Penal Code, if any, was undoubtedly complete when the appellant had moved the Tehsildar for action. Section 182 does not require that action must always be taken if the person who moves the public servant knows or believes that action would be taken.

anchor.surface_text: Now the offence under s. 182 of the Penal Code, if any, was undoubtedly complete when the appellant had moved the Tehsildar for action. Section 182 does not require that action must always be taken if the person who moves the public servant knows or believes that action would be taken. In making his report to the Tehsildar therefore, if the appellant believed that some action would be taken  and he had numberreason to doubt that it would number  the offence under that section was companyplete.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual reading of s.182 IPC: offence completes on giving false info with belief in likely action by public servant, irrespective of whether action follows.

holdings.text: No Court shall take cognizance of any offence punishable under sections 172 to 188 IPC except on the complaint in writing of the public servant concerned, or of some other public servant to whom he is subordinate; the court must be moved by the appropriate public servant.

anchor.surface_text: The words of s. 195 of the Criminal Procedure Code are explicit. The section reads as follows No Court shall take companynizance- a  of any offence punishable under sections 172 to 188 of the Indian Penal Code, except on the companyplaint in writing of the public servant companycerned, or of some other public servant to whom he is subordinate The words of the section, namely, that the companyplaint has to be in writing by the public servant companycerned and that numbercourt shall take companynizance except on such a companyplaint clearly show that in every instance the companyrt must be moved by the appropriate public servant.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct textual interpretation of s.195 CrPC mandates written complaint by specific public servant as prerequisite for cognizance.

holdings.text: The words 'no court shall take cognizance' have been interpreted on more than one occasion and they show that there is an absolute bar against the court taking seisin of the case except in the manner provided by the section.

anchor.surface_text: We have to decide therefore whether the Tehsildar can be said to be the public servant companycerned and if he had number filed the companyplaint in writing, whether the police officers in filing the charge sheet had satisfied the requirements of s. 195. The words numbercourt shall take companynizance have been interpreted on more than one occasion and they show that there is an absolute bar against the companyrt taking seisin of the case except in the manner provided by the section.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prior interpretations confirm absolute jurisdictional bar on cognizance without compliant complaint under s.195.

holdings.text: A complaint by the Tehsildar was not filed at all, but a charge sheet was put in by the Station House Officer; the Tehsildar's request for a calendar does not constitute due compliance with s.195.

anchor.surface_text: The learned companynsel for the State Government tries to support the action by submitting that s. 195 had been companyplied with inasmuch as when the allegations had been disproved, the letter of the Superintendent of Police was forwarded to the Tehsildar and he asked for a calendar. This paper was flied along with the charge sheet and it is stated that this satisfies the requirements of s. 195. In our opinion, this is number a due companypliance with the provisions of that section. What the section companytemplates is that the companyplaint must be in writing by the public servant companycerned and there is numbersuch companypliance in the present case. On the other hand what we find is that a companyplaint by the Tehsildar was number filed at all, but a charge sheet was put in by the Station House Officer.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Factual finding: no written complaint by Tehsildar; police action and informal request insufficient to meet statutory requirement.

holdings.text: The cognizance of the case was therefore wrongly assumed by the court without the complaint in writing of the public servant namely the Tehsildar in this case. The trial was thus without jurisdiction ab initio and the conviction cannot be maintained.

anchor.surface_text: The companynizance of the case was therefore wrongly assumed by the companyrt without the companyplaint in writing of the public servant namely the Tehsildar in this case. The trial was thus without jurisdiction ab inito and the companyviction cannot be maintained.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of s.195 bar to facts: lack of complaint vitiates jurisdiction from inception, rendering conviction void.

anchor.surface_text: The companynizance of the case was therefore wrongly assumed by the companyrt without the companyplaint in writing of the public servant namely the Tehsildar in this case. The trial was thus without jurisdiction ab inito and the companyviction cannot be maintained.

anchor.surface_text: The public servant who was moved by the appellant was undoubtedly the Tehsildar. Whether the appellant wanted the Tehsildar to take action or number, the fact remains that he moved the Tehsildar on what is stated to be a false averment of facts. He had charged Hans Raj and Kans Raj with offences under the Penal Code and he had moved his superior officer for action even though he might have stated in the letter that it was only for his information. We are prepared to assume that he expected that some action would be taken. In fact his second letter that he had companypromised the matter and the proceedings might be dropped clearly shows that he anticipated some action on the part of his superior officer.

The companynizance of the case was therefore wrongly assumed by the companyrt without the companyplaint in writing of the public servant namely the Tehsildar in this case. The trial was thus without jurisdiction ab inito and the companyviction cannot be maintained.

anchor.surface_text: Now the offence under s. 182 of the Penal Code, if any, was undoubtedly complete when the appellant had moved the Tehsildar for action. Section 182 does not require that action must always be taken if the person who moves the public servant knows or believes that action would be taken. In making his report to the Tehsildar therefore, if the appellant believed that some action would be taken  and he had numberreason to doubt that it would number  the offence under that section was companyplete.

anchor.surface_text: The words of s. 195 of the Criminal Procedure Code are explicit. The section reads as follows No Court shall take companynizance- a  of any offence punishable under sections 172 to 188 of the Indian Penal Code, except on the companyplaint in writing of the public servant companycerned, or of some other public servant to whom he is subordinate The words of the section, namely, that the companyplaint has to be in writing by the public servant companycerned and that numbercourt shall take companynizance except on such a companyplaint clearly show that in every instance the companyrt must be moved by the appropriate public servant.

The companynizance of the case was therefore wrongly assumed by the companyrt without the companyplaint in writing of the public servant namely the Tehsildar in this case. The trial was thus without jurisdiction ab inito and the companyviction cannot be maintained.
